4.1.2.4.	Safeguards that control, prevent/mitigate or reduce the consequences and a release, and prevent contamination or fire   
4.1.2.5.	Steps to detect or monitor releases
The HR results have been documented and are retained on file at the facility.  Implementation of the HR recommendations is ongoing and essentially a continuing process.  The Hazard Review shall be updated minimally every 5 years or with any process or equipment change that occurs that impacts the covered processes. 
4.1.3.	OPERATING PROCEDURES	68.52
Geocycle has written operating procedures (OPs) that describe in detail what tasks a process operator must perform.  The OPs set safe process operating parameters that must be maintained.  It lists the set safety precautions for operations and maintenance activities.  These procedures are the guide for employees on how to work safely, providing a readily accessible source of comprehensive information that can prevent or mitigate the effects of an accident.  Finally, it provides workers and management with a standard against which to assess performance.
Geocycle has operating procedures for each of the following:
¿	Initial start-up
¿	Normal operations
¿	Temporary operations
¿	Emergency shutdown
¿	Emergency operations
¿	Normal shutdown
¿	Startup following a normal or emergency shutdown or a major change
¿	Consequence of deviation and steps required to avoid or correct deviations and
¿	Equipment inspection
Operating procedures are developed and implemented that cover recipe, analysis inventory control blending operations and direct burn operations.  These procedures are reviewed and updated any time there is a change in the process that alters the steps needed to operate safely.  Examples of changes that may require an update to the operating procedures include:  the installation of new operating equipment, a change in the safety information for the regulated chemical or proce

68.155 Executive Summary

Holcim US Inc/Geocycle LLC (Geocycle) facility in Holly Hill, South Carolina manages hazardous waste derived fuels (HWDF) that are used to reduce fossil fuel and natural raw material consumption in the Lafarge/Holcim Portland cement manufacturing facility.  The prevention program covers both Alternative Fuels and Secondary Raw Materials (AFR) Processes; direct burn and blended burn. Geocycle has prepared this plan and submitted a predictive RMP Plan to maintain future operational flexibility.  This summary includes a brief description of the key elements of our Level 2 program.

1.	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES (A)
Geocycle's prevention program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) 40 CFR-68, Level 2 Prevention Program.  Key polices which are implemented includes MSHA standards:
1.1.	MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (A) (1)
Geocycle has a management system that is led by the Facility Manager and supporting staff.  This is depicted in an organization chart which is attached.
1.2.	PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 2 (A) (2)
Geocycle maintains policies, procedures and systems as part of our prevention program.  It also includes all requirements for a RCRA hazardous waste facility.
1.3.	REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED AT GEOCYCLE, HOLLY HILL, SC SITE (B)
The Geocycle Plant employs 20 full-time employees engaged in HWDF plant. 

2.	STATIONARY SOURCE DESCRIPTION (B) (1)
The site is owned by Holcim (US) and is managed and operated by Geocycle.  The site is located at 2175 Gardner Blvd, Holly Hill, SC, Orangeburg County and is part of the cement kiln operations.

3.	REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED (B) (2)
HWDFs include both a flammable mixture and toxic chemicals.  These are listed in Section 1.17 Process Specific Information.
Process 1, Tank Farm/Blend Tank System that feeds AFR to the kiln and precalciner, covers a flammable mixture and 12 toxic chemicals.  
Process 2

, Direct Burn System feeds to the face of the kiln AFR chemicals, includes nine toxic as well as each Process number 1, flammable mixture and 12 toxic chemicals. 
4.	THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The Geocycle accidental release prevention program is based on EPA's RMP Level 2 prevention program.  Also, Geocycle HWDF policies and procedures meets RCRA requirements for a permitted hazardous waste treatment, storage and disposal facility and MSHA safety standards therefore the plant is exempt from OSHA standards.  
4.1.	GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (C) (1)
Plant-wide all elements of the prevention program are used for all operations.  An overview of the generally written program's elements is listed below:
4.1.1.	SAFETY INFORMATION	68.48
Geocycle compiled the safety information required under the RMP regulation.  The safety information assists in the understanding of the safety-related aspects of the equipment and processes, and the limitations placed on the operations and the adopted codes and standards.  
Geocycle receives hazardous waste, and uses a detailed chemical analysis and physical property analysis to define each waste stream.  There are no SDSs for hazardous waste.  However, a SDS of the individual components is used as a guide.  Also the information contained on the waste chemicals Safety Information Sheet is reviewed and updated on a periodic basis for completeness and accuracy.  The maximum intended inventory for each RMP Toxic Chemical is listed in the List of Chemicals in the RMP.  
The bulk containers used for delivering the waste fuel containing the RMP compounds are DOT-specification containers and are required to be tested periodically for tightness and adequacy for carrying hazardous materials.  
Documentation of the safety and design information on the typical process equipment, along with the corresponding design codes, is maintained in the plant's current RCRA Permit Ap

plication in Section 4 - Storage and Process Information (4.3 Hazardous Waste Management), Operations SOPs for Operating Limits and Temporary Operations, Engineering and Maintenance Records.  The 2011/2012 and 2018 EPD audit reports and equipment evaluation confirmed all of the process equipment installations were within NFPA code.  
4.1.2.	HAZARDS REVIEWS 68.50
The facility completed numerous hazard reviews (HR) of its RMP regulated process Hazardous Waste Derived Fuels (HWDF) facility operations.  A Hazard Review was conducted for the following years 
¿	Initial HR in December 1999.
¿	2001 Update of the 1999 HR.
¿	In September of 2006 a HR of the new Direct Burn and existing process.  Then in September 2009, a HR and compliance audit of the blend tanks and derived fuel system was conducted.
¿	In 2011 through 2012 a complete explosibility and electrical systems review was completed.  
¿	A Hazard Review was conducted on December 2012 of the RMP regulated process. The more complete Hazards and Operability (HazOp) technique was used for the 2012 and all subsequent reviews.
¿	A Hazard Review was conducted on October 31, 2014 of the improvements to the Vapor Recovery System and a Hazard Review was conducted on March 24, 2015 of the expansion of the Sprinkler System in the receiving areas.
¿	A Hazard Review was conducted on October 8th 2016 for the AFR Feed to the precalciner.  NOTE: other kiln feeds are injected into the face of the kiln.
¿	A Hazard Review was conducted on January 17 through the 19, 2018 for the entire process and included the addition of the under construction Burn Tank T-5106 and its related safety systems.
¿	A Hazard Review was conducted on May 16 through the 17, 2023 for the entire process as part of the RMP recertification.
Key areas covered in the HR 
4.1.2.1.	Each HR used a multidisciplinary team to conduct the evaluation that identified:
4.1.2.2.	Hazards associated with the process and regulated chemicals
4.1.2.3.	 Potential for equipment malfunc

ss equipment, as well as the identification of additional hazards during the updates to the facility hazard review.
4.1.3.1.	Extensive training programs are established in each area for subject employees and contractors; all receive initial and refresher training.  
4.1.4.	TRAINING	68.54
Under the RMP regulation in 40 CFR Part 68.54, all new workers and experienced workers are trained in the Operating Procedures prior to starting working on an RMP covered process and refresher training.  Also, training is given any time the procedures are revised and everyone is trained in using the new procedures.  Training for the RMP program is given at least once every three years.  Finally, training will be given more often if necessary; employees are consulted by Geocycle to establish refresher training regiments.  Refresher training is provided on the operating procedures, the chemicals, and requirements of the RMP regulation even if they have not changed.  The training must cover all parts of the operating procedures, including information on the consequences of deviations and steps needed to address deviations. 
Under the provisions of 40 CFR § 68.54(c), the facility "may use training conducted under Federal or state regulations or under industry specific standards or codes or training conducted by covered process equipment vendors to demonstrate compliance with this section to the extent that the training meets the requirements of this section".  Under the prevailing federal RCRA regulations, all HWDF facility and cement plant employees associated with hazardous waste operations are trained within 6 months of hire but prior to working independently on a process.  The training includes the following:
4.1.4.1. 24 Hours initial RCRA/MSHA hazardous waste operations and emergency training  
4.1.4.2.	8 hours RCRA/MSHA initial and annual refresher training
4.1.4.3.	Classroom and on-the-job training is conducted, along with written examinations as required.  All training logs and

records are maintained on site.
4.1.5.	MAINTENANCE	68.56
Preventive maintenance, calibrations, inspection, and testing of equipment are critical to safe operations.  Geocycle has developed and implemented procedures for maintaining the mechanical integrity of process equipment. We also train applicable workers and contractors in the maintenance procedures, under 40 CFR 68.52, 54 and 56. 
As required under 40 CFR 264/265, the facility has implemented Procedures to Prevent Hazards as an integral part of its hazardous waste management operations.  These written procedures meet or exceed the requirements for preventive maintenance, inspection and testing under the RMP regulations and are incorporated by reference.  They provide a detailed list of the equipment to be tested and the inspection frequency.  The schedules already in practice are based on: 
4.1.5.1.	Regulatory Compliance Requirements
4.1.5.2.	Manufacturer's Recommendations
4.1.5.3.	Industry Standards or Codes
4.1.5.4.	Good Engineering Practices
All employees associated with preventive maintenance, inspection and testing are trained in these procedures.
4.1.6.	COMPLIANCE AUDITS	 68.58
Geocycle will review and audit the RMP Plan every three years, at a minimum, to ensure that the plan is implemented and documented adequately.  The audit program is designed to evaluate and measure the effectiveness of the Risk Management Program and ensure that the prevention program elements are up-to-date and appropriate for current operations.
The most recent audit was conducted April 30, 2018 for the entire RMP processes.
The compliance audit will be conducted by an individuals or team; knowledgeable of both the regulated processes as well as the RMP regulations [40 CFR Part 68].  The compliance audit will include a review of all elements of the RMP plan level 2 program located in the EPA Audit Checklist, including:
4.1.6.1.	Safety Information
4.1.6.2.	Hazard Review
4.1.6.3.	Change in Regulated Process or Regulated Chemicals

4.1.6.4.	Records
4.1.6.5.	The RMP*eSubmittal
Upon completion of the compliance audit, all findings shall be summarized in a written report.  Geocycle will promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each audit finding and further document all corrective actions taken to address any deficiencies.  Copies of the two most recent compliance audits and documentation of all corrective actions will be maintained at the facility.
4.1.7.	INCIDENT INVESTIGATION	68.60
Geocycle will perform an investigation of each incident which has resulted in, or could have resulted in a release or catastrophic release of a regulated chemical.  A catastrophic release is one that presents an imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment.  A RMP reportable release is one that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
The following steps will be taken in performing an incident investigation:
4.1.7.1.	Initiate an investigation as promptly as possible, as but no later than 48 hours following the incident.
4.1.7.2.	Summarize the investigation in a report.  Incorporate all factors contributing to the incident including:  date of incident; date investigation began, a description of the incident; the factors that contributed to the incident; and any recommendations resulting from the investigation.
4.1.7.3.	Address the investigation findings and recommendations.  Resolutions and corrective actions shall be documented.
4.1.7.4.	The findings shall be reviewed with all affected personnel to prevent future occurrence of similar incidents.
4.1.7.5.	Each investigation report is maintained for a minimum of five years.
4.2.	HWDF-SPECIFIC RESPONSE PROGRAM (C) (2)
4.2.1.	Chemical-specific prevention for the plant includes the policies and procedures listed above and those of the HWDF specific program.  
4.2.2.	Facility and equipm

ent design meet recognized codes and good engineering standards, such as NFPA.  Recently the plant conducted an Explosion Prevention Survey that evaluated each electrical system to determine if it met the design and code requirements. The results were documented and recommendations were implemented.  The audit used NFPA standards as well as good engineering standards and those of our corporation.  The report recommendations were implemented and the report is maintained on site. All new equipment and installations are also evaluated.
4.3.	OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
To help develop the prevention program an offsite consequence analyses was conducted.  It was for a worst case and alternate case release scenario for each covered HWDF Process.  All results are maintained on site and included in the RMP Submit program.  
4.4.	WORST CASE (C) (1)
Atmospheric dispersion modeling for the worst case scenario was performed for the flammable mixture and each flammable and toxic chemical using the EPA's RMP-COMP program. This included separate models for the Blended Derived Fuels and separate Direct Burn operations. 
4.5.	ALTERNATIVE CASE (C) (2)
The alternative release scenario involves a 100-gallon-per-minute leak in a tank, pump, pipe or associated storage and transfer equipment.  Modeling was performed using the EPA's RMP COMP program based on duration of 60 minutes, which is a conservative assumption. This included separate models for the Blended Derived Fuels and separate Direct Burn operations.

5.	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (E)
There have been zero RMP accidental releases or injuries in the past five years.   Mistakenly a Non-RMP chemical release was entered into our previous submission.  This accident was removed from this report.

6.	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM (F)
Emergency response procedures are contained in both the Plant Emergency Response Policy and Contingency Plan (Emergency Response Plan, developed under RCRA requirements for a hazardous waste treatment storag

e and disposal facility).  Geocycle is a non-responding facility our operators are trained to the HAZMAT Operations level and the Emergency Response Program meets RMP 68.95 described in Section 7 of this plan.  The plan is updated as needed and copies of the plan are submitted to our LEPC and local fire/rescue hazmat team.

7.	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 
Changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified in the internal and subsequent safety Hazards Analysis, tours, and audits used to upgrade all RMP program elements.  Geocycle continually reviews implemented operating procedures for potential safety improvements for all of its operations.  Planned changes including installation of automated fire foam monitors at the existing five 40,000 gallon blend tanks and the 250,000 gallon Feed Tank T-7101. A detailed evaluation to confirm that all electrical devices for the new 250,000 gallon Burn Tank (T-5106) meet NFPA Code standards was conducted in May 2018 (EPD Study).
We also follow MSHA regulations which include compliance with their regulations.
